name: Wireless (802.11)
description: Wireless networking based on IEEE 802.11 standards enables devices to connect to networks without physical cables. Key topics include SSIDs, security methods, and access point configuration.
key_topics: 802.11 standards: a, b, g, n, ac, ax (WiFi 6)
SSID (Service Set Identifier) and broadcast settings
Wireless security: WEP (deprecated), WPA, WPA2, WPA3
Wireless LAN Controller (WLC) and lightweight APs
CAPWAP (Control and Provisioning of Wireless Access Points)
common_misconceptions: Many training resources claim WEP is adequate for home networks. Cisco documentation emphasizes WEP is completely broken and should NEVER be used; minimum is WPA2 with AES

Third-party materials often confuse SSID broadcast disabling with security. Cisco guides clarify that hiding SSID provides no real security - it only prevents casual discovery but can be detected easily

Training books frequently oversimplify wireless security. Cisco emphasizes 802.1X with RADIUS (WPA2-Enterprise) is required for enterprise environments; PSK (WPA2-Personal) is acceptable only for small offices
Common error: assuming all 802.11n devices use 5 GHz. 802.11n works on both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands, unlike 802.11a (5 GHz only) and 802.11b/g (2.4 GHz only)
